title: Cell phones and cancer: 9 things you should know right now - CNET
paragraphs: Is Facebook secretly building a phone?
After a 6-year break, I'm playing World of Warcraft again.
The debate over whether cell phone use is hazardous to your health isn't over, and it may never be.
That trend isn't going to change anytime soon.
Despite what this study has demonstrated, and how some headlines have interpreted it, there's still no definitive answer to whether cell phones are dangerous.
And as I'll discuss in a minute, we may never get one at all.
This one study is not a reason to stop using your phone, and in today's modern world it would be near impossible to do so.
Still, it is OK for you to pay attention to this debate and be aware of its developments.
If you're just getting caught up, here's what you need to know.
Science takes time -- a lot of it.
Consider how long humans smoked before the evidence that it's harmful began to influence public policy.
Cell phones, however, are still a new technology.
We need more data to be certain of anything, Dr. Jana Witt, Cancer Research UK's health information officer told me in a phone interview.
It's difficult to get definitive answer or proof.
In other words, don't pine for a magical day when we we can say without any doubt that cell phones cause cancer.
In an emailed statement, Dr. Witt wrote that it's also unclear how the findings of a study on rats would translate to people.

There's been a lot of research into any potential cancer risk of using mobile phones and overall there's good evidence that the risk of brain tumours isn't higher in people who have used a mobile phone for up to 10 years, she wrote.
Ongoing research to check for effects over a longer time, or in children, is important.
It's also wise to consider who funds a study when evaluating its findings.
For example, would you inherently trust a study from the National Beef Association recommending that you eat steak once a week?
Two years ago, though, we discontinued the charts because a SAR by itself isn't a reliable measure of whether a phone is safe.
A handset may have a SAR of 0.9 w/kg, but that's not necessarily safer than a phone with 1.2 w/kg.
A handset's SAR can vary widely during a call as you alternate between transmission bands and as you increase your distance from a tower.
And it may never reach the highest recorded SAR found in the FCC test at all.
What's more, radiation -- at least in low doses -- is everywhere, even before the advent of wireless technology.
We'll never get away from it completely: We're addicted to Wi-Fi, and we use baby monitors, walkie-talkies and cordless phones.
Not all of it is harmful.
It continues because it's a good question to ask.
There a lot of studies that are still happening and we're still gathering data for, Dr. Witt told me.
The evidence will become clearer in the future.
I used to get a lot of email labeling people concerned about cell phones use as fear-mongering nuts.
That's an unfair generalization to make.
Instead, consider that many are intelligent, sincere and well-intentioned people.
Some have lost loved ones to brain cancer and worry that cell phone is a possible cause.
They're not just peddling nonsense, they're looking for answers and they want to save others from the same fate.
On a more personal note, I'll never forget one of the first things a good friend asked me after he was diagnosed with brain cancer in 2009 (he passed away four years later).
Do you think it could be my phone?
I replied with what I knew about the debate at the time, but realized it would be of little comfort.
But he just wanted to know, Why me?
Text instead of placing a voice call and use a headset to keep the phone away from your head when possible.
If you're pregnant, avoid carrying a phone next to your stomach or in your bra.
Men: Don't carry the phone in a pants pocket next to your groin.
Limit phone use for children, who have smaller and thinner skulls.
Don't sleep with an active phone under the pillow.
Put it on your bedside table instead.
And if you need to keep your phone on for middle-of-the-night emergency calls, at least silence text alerts so you can get a restful night's sleep.
In this week's wrap-up, the newest Uber app syncs up with your personal information to be more helpful.
Meanwhile, Samsung recalls 2.8 million top-loading washing machines.

        window.console && console.log && console.log("ADS: queuing mpu-plus-top-581e81051bf2b for display");
        var cbsiGptDivIds = cbsiGptDivIds || [];
        cbsiGptDivIds.push("mpu-plus-top-581e81051bf2b");
    </script></div><p>In the 12 years that I've covered wireless industry for CNET, the debate over whether cell phone use is hazardous to our health has <a href="https://www.cnet.com/uk/news/cell-phone-radiation-harmless-or-health-risk/">long simmered</a> in the background. It comes to a boil each time a new study analyzing a possible link is released, briefly grabbing the attention of the phone-wielding public.</p><p>The latest flash came May 26 when the US National Toxicology Program <a href="https://www.cnet.com/news/us-government-study-suggests-link-between-smartphones-and-cancer/">published a multiyear study</a> that found a potential link between phone use and cancer. Male rats that were exposed to the same wireless signals our cell phones emit today were more likely to develop certain types of brain and heart tumors than the control rats. The more exposure a rat received, the study reported, the more likely is was to develop a cancer of some form. No difference was observed between female rats; findings from mice subjects have yet to be disclosed (the full report from the study will be released next year).</p><p>The study's observations, especially when relayed quickly in our sound bite news culture, have alarmed some people. I understand why. In my years covering this issue, passions on the debate run deep. Some readers and <a href="https://www.cnet.com/uk/news/researchers-strong-signal-on-cell-phone-risk-q-a/">experts are convinced</a> we're on the verge of a major public health crisis, while others dismiss the debate as tinfoil-hat pseudoscience. Most of the public, however, doesn't appear to care. Ever since scientists first started asking questions, cell phone use has only skyrocketed with 92 percent of Americans now owning mobile phones.</p><p>That trend isn't going to change anytime soon. Nor should it. Despite what this study has demonstrated, and how some headlines have interpreted it, there's still no definitive answer to whether cell phones are dangerous. And as I'll discuss in a minute, we may never get one at all. This one study is not a reason to stop using your phone, and in today's modern world it would be near impossible to do so. Still, it is OK for you to pay attention to this debate and be aware of its developments. If you're just getting caught up, here's what you need to know.</p><h3>Take no study in a vacuum</h3><p>Remember that this is just one study in a crowded field that has been running for decades. Previous studies also <a href="https://www.cnet.com/news/who-cell-phones-may-cause-cancer/">have found links</a> between phone use and cancer, while others <a href="https://www.cnet.com/news/phones-do-not-cause-brain-cancer-study-says/">have found no correlation</a> (there are far too many to list here).</p><div id="inpage-video-top-581e81051bf2b" class="ad-inpage-video-top" data-ad="inpage-video-top"><script>
        window.console && console.log && console.log("ADS: queuing inpage-video-top-581e81051bf2b for display");
        var cbsiGptDivIds = cbsiGptDivIds || [];
        cbsiGptDivIds.push("inpage-video-top-581e81051bf2b");
    </script></div><p>As with many other things that scientists study in our universe, there's no consensus as of yet. Studies will differ, they will dispute each other and they will ask new questions we haven't asked before. Don't rely on <em>one</em> study to draw conclusions in your head, that's not how science works.</p><h3>We may never get an answer </h3><p>Science takes time -- a lot of it. Consider how long humans smoked before the evidence that it's harmful began to influence public policy. Cell phones, however, are still a new technology. "We need more data to be certain of anything," Dr. Jana Witt, Cancer Research UK's health information officer told me in a phone interview. "It's difficult to get definitive answer or proof."</p><p>Dr. Witt told me her organization would look for a comprehensive review of <em>all</em> available evidence showing a link. "We'd look at epidemiological (the science of how disease spreads) studies of humans that show a correlation, even if they may not be able to show a causation directly," she said. "They'd be combined with lab studies showing that [cell phone radiation] changes genetic material and studies of animals."</p><p>In other words, don't pine for a magical day when we we can say without any doubt that cell phones cause cancer. Likewise, don't wait for science to "prove" that phone use is not harmful. </p><h3>Consider every study carefully</h3><p>When any study is published, it will (rightfully) be analyzed and picked apart to find weaknesses or errors with the research. That's an important step that aids in further study. I won't do that here, <a href="http://arstechnica.com/science/2016/05/study-that-found-cell-phones-cause-cancer-in-rats-is-riddled-with-red-flags/" target="_blank" data-component="externalLink">leaving it to others</a> to point out the red flags instead.</p><div class="shortcode related-links float_left" section="shortcodeRelatedLinks">
        <h6>
                            <span>A long history of research</span>
                    </h6>
        <ul><li><a href="https://www.cnet.com/news/us-government-study-suggests-link-between-smartphones-and-cancer/">US government study suggests link between phones and cancer</a></li>

                                                                                                                <li><a href="https://www.cnet.com/news/phones-do-not-cause-brain-cancer-study-says/">Phones don't cause brain cancer, latest study says</a></li>

                                                                                                                <li><a href="https://www.cnet.com/news/link-between-cell-phones-and-cancer-may-be-unjustified/">Link between cell phones and cancer may be unjustified</a></li>

                                                                                                                <li><a href="https://www.cnet.com/news/who-cell-phones-may-cause-cancer/">WHO: Cell phones may cause cancer</a></li>

                                                                                                                <li><a href="https://www.cnet.com/uk/news/results-of-cell-phone-cancer-study-inconclusive/">Results of cell phone cancer study inconclusive</a></li>

                                                        </ul></div><p>Those include how the rats were exposed to emissions (nine hours per day and over their entire bodies is different how humans would use a cell phone), the type of rats used and their ages, whether the study was properly reviewed, small sample sizes and the fact that the study reported a "low incidence" of cancer in the test rats. </p><p>In an emailed statement, Dr. Witt wrote that it's also unclear how the findings of a study on rats would translate to people. "There's been a lot of research into any potential cancer risk of using mobile phones and overall there's good evidence that the risk of brain tumours isn't higher in people who have used a mobile phone for up to 10 years," she wrote. "Ongoing research to check for effects over a longer time, or in children, is important."</p><p>It's also wise to consider who funds a study when evaluating its findings. For example, would you inherently trust a study from the National Beef Association recommending that you eat steak once a week? No, of course not. </p><h3>About a phone's SAR </h3><p>For a long time CNET kept comprehensive cell phone radiation charts, which showed the maximum SAR (aka Specific Absorption Rate or how much radio frequency a phone emits) for every phone we reviewed. </p><p>As background, the Federal Communications Commission <a href="https://www.fcc.gov/engineering-technology/electromagnetic-compatibility-division/radio-frequency-safety/faq/rf-safety" target="_blank" data-component="externalLink">mandates that every phone</a> sold in the US must have a SAR of no higher than 1.6 watts/kilogram (w/kg). Before it can go on sale, the FCC tests a phone to find its SAR in facility in Maryland (though some health advocates charge that the FCC test <a href="https://www.cnet.com/news/u-s-report-fccs-cell-phone-radiation-guidelines-outdated/">is outdated</a>). Canada also has a 1.6 w/kg limit, while the European Union and Australia mandate a 2.0 w/kg limit. </p><p>Two years ago, though, we discontinued the charts because a SAR by itself isn't a reliable measure of whether a phone is safe. A handset may have a SAR of 0.9 w/kg, but that's not necessarily safer than a phone with 1.2 w/kg. A handset's SAR can vary widely during a call as you alternate between transmission bands and as you increase your distance from a tower. And it may never reach the highest recorded SAR found in the FCC test at all.</p><h3>What the industry says</h3><p>Not surprisingly, the wireless industry, led by the Cellular Telecommunications Industry Association in the US, <a href="http://www.cellphonehealthfacts.com/most-asked-questions" target="_blank" data-component="externalLink">is quick to insist that phone use is safe</a>. It cites studies that back up this position and is critical of studies that say differently. The CTIA also has pushed back vigorously against local governments that have tried to mandate health warnings to cell phone use. </p><p>In 2013 after a lawsuit from the CTIA, for instance, the San Francisco Board of Supervisors <a href="https://www.cnet.com/news/san-francisco-finally-kills-cell-phone-radiation-law/">voted to kill a law</a> that would have forced phone retailers to list a handset's SAR at the point of sale. Though similar legislation has mostly stalled in other cities this year, the nearby city of Berkeley was able to <a href="http://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/Berkeleys-Right-to-Know-Cell-Phone-Radiation-Warning-Ordinance-Now-in-Effect-373027781.html" target="_blank" data-component="externalLink">implement</a> a law mandating health notices after a federal judge <a href="http://www.berkeleyside.com/2016/01/28/federal-judge-upholds-berkeley-cellphone-warning/" target="_blank" data-component="externalLink">dismissed</a> a CTIA suit.</p><p>Again, think about what happened with smoking. Even <em>if</em> the scientific community were to reach a consensus that wireless signals are likely to cause cancer, drafting safety legislation and changing public behavior will be a long battle the industry will be intimately involved in. </p><h3>What the skeptics say </h3><p>Those doubting a link between phone use and cancer raise a number of great questions. For instance, if cell phones really are dangerous, then why are <a href="http://seer.cancer.gov/statfacts/html/brain.html" target="_blank" data-component="externalLink">brain cancer rates falling</a>? Others contend that phones emit far less radiation than could ever be considered harmful and the kind of radiation (non-ionizing) they emit can't adversely affect human cells.</p><p>What's more, radiation -- at least in low doses -- is everywhere, even before the advent of wireless technology. We'll never get away from it completely: We're addicted to Wi-Fi, and we use baby monitors, walkie-talkies and cordless phones. Not all of it is harmful.</p><h3>Why study continues</h3><p>It continues because it's a good question to ask. "There a lot of studies that are still happening and we're still gathering data for," Dr. Witt told me. "The evidence will become clearer in the future."</p><p>And it isn't just about brain cancer. Cell phone use is affecting our bodies in other ways. They keep us awake at night, give us sore necks and texting thumbs and make us more distracted. Texting and driving is incredibly dangerous and some studies have suggested that phones could <a href="https://www.prlog.org/12269207-cell-phone-use-and-prenatal-exposure-to-cell-phone-radiation-may-cause-headaches-in-children.html" target="_blank" data-component="externalLink">give children headaches</a> or <a href="http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2014-06/uoe-mpn060914.php" target="_blank" data-component="externalLink">decrease male fertility</a>. Maybe we'll have to wait until kids raised with cell phone are well into adulthood to know more.</p><h3>Don't dismiss health advocates out of hand</h3><div id="mpu-bottom-581e81051bf2b" class="ad-mpu-bottom" data-ad="mpu-bottom"><script>
        window.console && console.log && console.log("ADS: queuing mpu-bottom-581e81051bf2b for display");
        var cbsiGptDivIds = cbsiGptDivIds || [];
        cbsiGptDivIds.push("mpu-bottom-581e81051bf2b");
    </script></div><p>I used to get a lot of email labeling people concerned about cell phones use as fear-mongering nuts. That's an unfair generalization to make. Instead, consider that many are intelligent, sincere and well-intentioned people. Some have lost loved ones to brain cancer and worry that cell phone is a possible cause. They're not just peddling nonsense, they're looking for answers and they want to save others from the same fate. Let's meet them halfway.</p><p>On a more personal note, I'll never forget one of the first things a good friend asked me after he was diagnosed with brain cancer in 2009 (he passed away four years later). "Do you think it could be my phone?" he asked. I replied with what I knew about the debate at the time, but realized it would be of little comfort. But he just wanted to know, "Why me?"</p><h3>What you can do</h3><p>If you are concerned, here's what you can do. Most of these precautions are recommended by and the <a href="http://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/causes-prevention/risk/radiation/cell-phones-fact-sheet" target="_blank" data-component="externalLink">National Cancer Institute</a> and the <a href="http://www.cdc.gov/nceh/radiation/cell_phones._FAQ.html" target="_blank" data-component="externalLink">Centers for Disease Control and Prevention</a> in the US, the UK's <a href="http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Mobile-phone-safety/Pages/Introduction.aspx" target="_blank" data-component="externalLink">National Health Service</a> and the <a href="http://www.arpansa.gov.au/radiationprotection/factsheets/is_Wireless.cfm" target="_blank" data-component="externalLink">Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency</a>. And even if you think these simple steps are silly, consider that following them isn't going to <em>harm</em> you.</p><ul><li>Text instead of placing a voice call and use a headset to keep the phone away from your head when possible.</li><li>If you're pregnant, avoid carrying a phone next to your stomach or in your bra.</li><li>Men: Don't carry the phone in a pants pocket next to your groin.</li><li>Limit phone use for children, who have smaller and thinner skulls.</li><li>Don't sleep with an active phone under the pillow. Put it on your bedside table instead. And if you need to keep your phone on for middle-of-the-night emergency calls, at least silence text alerts so you can get a restful night's sleep.</li><li>Be careful with accessories promising protection. Pong's line of phones cases promise <a href="https://www.cnet.com/news/a-cell-phone-case-for-reducing-cell-phone-radiation/">to refocus RF energy</a> away from your head while not reducing signal strength. Again, though, there's no guarantee that such a case makes your phone safer. Don't bother with the shiny, gold-lined radiation "shields" you can find online. They're <a href="http://www.fda.gov/Radiation-EmittingProducts/RadiationEmittingProductsandProcedures/HomeBusinessandEntertainment/CellPhones/ucm116293.htm" target="_blank" data-component="externalLink">useless</a>.</li></ul></div><footer><div class="row collections-topics-and-tags" section="tag"><dl><dt><b><a href="/tags/">Tags: </a></b></dt><dd><a
